cards.title: Intro
cards.body: The Rust quick reference cheat sheet that aims at providing help on writing basic syntax and methods.

cards.title: Hello_World.rs
cards.body: #### Compiling and Running

cards.title: Primitive types
cards.body: See: [Rust Types](#rust-types)

cards.title: Formatting
Formatting
cards.body:
// Multiple Placeholder
println!("{} {}", 1, 3);

cards.title: Formatting
Formatting
Formatting
cards.body:
// Placeholder traits :b for binary, :0x is for hex and :o is octal
println!("Let us print 76 is binary which is {:b} , and hex equivalent is {:0x} and octal equivalent is {:o}", 76, 76, 76);

cards.title: Formatting
Formatting
Formatting
cards.body:
// Prints the output
print!("Hello World\n");

cards.title: Formatting
cards.body:
// Appends a new line after printing
println!("Appending a new line");

cards.title: Formatting
cards.body:
// Prints as an error
eprint!("This is an error\n");

cards.title: Formatting
cards.body:
// Prints as an error with new line
eprintln!("This is an error with new line");

cards.title: Formatting
cards.body:
// Initializing and declaring a variable
let some_variable = "This_is_a_variable";

cards.title: Formatting
cards.body:

let mut mutable_variable = "Mutable";

cards.title: Formatting
cards.body:
// Assigning multiple variables
let (name, age) = ("ElementalX", 20);

cards.title: Formatting
cards.body:
// (Global) constant
const SCREAMING_SNAKE_CASE: i64 = 9;

cards.body:
let community_name = "AXIAL";
let no_of_members: &str = "ten";

cards.title: Formatting
cards.body: println!("The name of the community is {community_name} and it has {no_of_members} members");

cards.title: Formatting
cards.body: let mut array: [i32; 3] = [2, 6, 10];

cards.title: Formatting
cards.body:
array[1] = 4;
array[2] = 6;

cards.title: Formatting
cards.code:
Use the `mut` keyword to make it mutable.

### Slices

cards.title: Formatting
cards.body:
let mut array: [i64; 4] = [1, 2, 3, 4];
let mut slices: &[i64] = &array[0..3]; // Lower range is inclusive and upper range is exclusive

cards.title: Formatting
cards.body: println!("The elements of the slices are : {slices:?}");

cards.title: Formatting
cards.body: let some_vector = vec![1, 2, 3, 4, 5];

cards.title: Formatting
cards.code:
A vector is declared using the `vec!` macro.

### Tuples

cards.title: Formatting
cards.body: let tuple = (1, 'A', "Cool", 78, true);

cards.title: Formatting
cards.body: let cs: &str = "cheat sheet";

cards.title: Formatting
cards.body:
// => Share cheat sheet for developers
println!("Share {cs} for developers");

cards.title: Formatting
cards.body:
// Creating an empty string object
let my_string = String::new();

cards.title: Formatting
cards.body:
// Converting to a string object
let S_string = a_string.to_string();

cards.title: Formatting
Formatting
cards.body:
let rand = String::from("Random String");
rand.capacity() // => 13

cards.title: Formatting
cards.code:
Calculates the capacity of the string in bytes.

### .contains()

cards.title: Formatting
cards.body:
let name = String::from("ElementalX");
name.contains("Element") // => true

cards.title: Formatting
cards.code:
Checks if the substring is contained inside the original string or not.

### Pushing a single character

cards.title: Formatting
cards.body:
let mut half_text = String::from("Hal");
half_text.push('f'); // => Half

cards.title: Formatting
cards.body:
let mut hi = String::from("Hey there...");
hi.push_str("How are you doing??");

cards.title: Formatting
cards.body:
// => Hey there...How are you doing??
println!("{hi}");

cards.title: Formatting
cards.code:
## Rust Operators

### Comparison Operators

|          |                                  |
| -------- | :------------------------------- |
| `e == f` | `e` is equal to `f`              |
| `e != f` | `e` is NOT equal to `f`          |
| `e < f`  | `e` is less than `f`             |
| `e > f`  | `e` is greater than `f`          |
| `e <= f` | `e` is less than or equal to `f` |
| `e >= f` | `e` is greater or equal to `f`   |

---

cards.title: Formatting
cards.body:
let greater = f > e;        // => true
let less = f < e;           // => false
let greater_equal = f >= e; // => true
let less_equal = e <= f;    // => true
let equal_to = e == f;      // => false
let not_equal_to = e != f;  // => true

cards.title: Formatting
cards.code:
### Arithmetic Operators

|          |                                            |
| -------- | :----------------------------------------- |
| `a +  b` | `a` is added to `b`                        |
| `a -  b` | `b` is subtracted from `a`                 |
| `a /  b` | `a` is divided by `b`                      |
| `a % b`  | Gets remainder of `a` by dividing with `b` |
| `a * b`  | `a` is multiplied with `b`                 |

---

cards.title: Formatting
cards.body:
let sum: i32 = a + b;            // => 9
let subtractions: i32 = a - b;   // => -1
let multiplication: i32 = a * b; // => 20
let division: i32 = a / b;       // => 0
let modulus: i32 = a % b;        // => 4

cards.title: Formatting
cards.code: ### Bitwise Operators | Operator | Description | | ------------------- | ----------------------- | | `g & h` | Binary AND | | g \| h | Binary OR | | `g ^ h` | Binary XOR | | `!g` | Binary one's complement | | `g << h` | Binary shift left | | `g >> h` | Binary shift right | ---

cards.title: Formatting
cards.body:
let bitwise_and = g & h;  // => 0
let bitwise_or = g | h;   // => 3
let bitwise_xor = g ^ h;  // => 3
let right_shift = g >> 2; // => 0
let left_shift = h << 4;  // => 32

cards.title: Formatting
cards.code: ### Logical Operators | Example | Meaning | | --------------------- | --------------------- | | `c && d` | Both are true _(AND)_ | | c \|\| d | Either is true _(OR)_ | | `!c` | `c` is false _(NOT)_ | ---

cards.title: Formatting
cards.body: let (c, d) = (true, false);

cards.title: Formatting
cards.body:
let and = c && d;  // => false
let or = c || d;   // => true
let not = !c;      // => false

cards.title: Formatting
cards.body:
let mut k = 9;
let mut l = k;

cards.title: Formatting
cards.code: --- | Operator | Description | | -------------------- | --------------------------------------- | | `k += l` | Add a value and assign, then k=18 | | `k -= l` | Subtract a value and assign, then k=0 | | `k /= l` | Divide a value and assign, then k=1 | | `k *= l` | Multiply a value and assign, then k=81 | | k \|= l | Bitwise OR and assign, then k=89 | ## Rust Flow Control ### If Expression

let case2: i32 = 82;

let case4 = 9;

### Borrowing

cards.title: Formatting
Formatting
Formatting
cards.code:
Here borrowed value borrows the value from value one using `&` operator.

### De-referencing

cards.title: Formatting
cards.body:
let mut borrow = 10;
let deref = &mut borrow;

cards.title: Formatting
cards.body: println!("{}", *deref);

cards.title: Formatting
cards.code:
De-referencing in rust can be done using the `*` operator
